tit.e: Okimi no tsukasa (an official of the Imperial Family registry office)
tit.cmt: an official of the Imperial Family registry office→Imperial Family Officeとし、全角スペースを半角に修正、タイトルの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 正親司（おおきみのつかさ）は日本古代の律令制において宮内省に属する機関の一つである。
sen.e: Okimi no tsukasa is one of the institutions belonging to Imperial Household Agency in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.
Okimi no tsukasa was one of the institutions belonging to Imperial Household Agency in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.
Okimi no tsukasa was one of the institutions belonging to Imperial Household Agency in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.

sen.j: 「おおきんだちのつかさ」とも。
sen.e: It is also called "Okindachi no tsukasa."
It is also called 'Okindachi no tsukasa.'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: It is also called 'Okindachi no tsukasa.'

sen.j: 正親司は皇籍を管理し皇族への給与（季禄・時服）に関する事務を執り行う。
sen.e: Okimi no tsukasa administered the register of the Imperial family and did an office work concerning the salary (kiroku (salary paid to the officers under the ritsuryo system), jifuku (allocations of cloth)) to the Imperial family.

Okimi no tsukasa administered the register of the Imperial family and did office work concerning the salary (kiroku [salary paid to the officers under the ritsuryo system], jifuku [allocations of cloth]) to the Imperial family.

Okimi no tsukasa administered the register of the Imperial family and did office work concerning the salary (kiroku [salary paid to the officers under the ritsuryo system], jifuku [allocations of cloth]) to the Imperial family.

sen.j: 令制以前にはこのような機関は無く、唐の律令制における宗正寺（そうせいじ）を模倣したと考えられる。
sen.e: Before the Ritsuryo system, there was no such institution and it is considered to have imitated Sosei-ji Temple in the Ritsuryo system during the Tang Dynasty.
Before the Ritsuryo system, there was no such institution and it is considered to have imitated the Court of the Imperial Clan (Zongzheng Si) in the Ritsuryo system during the Tang Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 宗正寺→寺の名前ではなく唐の機関名のため、Sosei-ji Temple→the Court of the Imperial Clan (Zongzheng Si)としました。(参照:http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=EXVk1tr6lEYC&pg=PA370&dq=Zongzheng+Si&hl=ja&ei=E4U9TJKFN4mYvAOXg7XdDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Zongzheng%20Si&f=false)
sen.e: Before the Ritsuryo system, there was no such institution and it is considered to have imitated the Court of the Imperial Clan (Zongzheng Si) in the Ritsuryo system during the Tang Dynasty.

sen.j: 皇族の名簿を管理するため、長官の正には奈良時代には王が任命されることが多く、平安時代以後は代々白川家（花山源氏・伯王家）が任じられた。
sen.e: To control the name list of Imperial families, kings were often appointed to Okimi, who was an administrator, during Nara period and after Heian period SHIRAKAWA families (Kazan Genji (Minamoto clan), Haku o ke (the Haku o Family)) were appointed for generations.

To control the name list of Imperial families, princes were often appointed to Kami, who was an administrator, during the Nara period and after the Heian period the Shirakawa family (Kazan-Genji [Minamoto clan], the Hakuo family) were appointed for generations.
sen.cmt: during the Nara period、after the Heian periodとし、kings→princes、Okimi→Kami、SHIRAKAWA families→the Shirakawa family、Kazan Genji→Kazan-Genji、Haku o ke (the Haku o Family)→the Hakuo familyに修正、カッコ表記修正
sen.e: To control the name list of Imperial families, princes were often appointed to Kami, who was an administrator, during the Nara period and after the Heian period the Shirakawa family (Kazan-Genji [Minamoto clan], the Hakuo family) were appointed for generations.

sen.j: 司であるにもかかわらず他の司のように統廃合されることがなく､逆に別当が正の上に置かれた。
sen.e: Though they were a tsukasa, they were not abolished or merged like the other tsukasa and conversely betto (chief officer) was put on Okimi.
Though its government department was a tsukasa, this office was not abolished or merged like the other tsukasa and conversely betto (chief officer) was put above Kami.
sen.cmt: they were a tsukasa→its government department was a tsukasa、they were not→this office was not、on→above、Okimi→Kamiに修正
sen.e: Unlike other tsukasa, Okimi no Tsukasa was never abolished or merged; rather 'betto' (chief officer) was ranked above 'kami' (equivalent to Shorokuinojo [Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade]) within the institution.
sen.cmt: 内容を修正しました。Tsukasa については、すでに説明があるので省略しました。

sen.j: 別当は貴族がつとめその機関を総裁する職で寮に置かれることが多く､司では他に内膳司にしか置かれていない。
sen.e: Aristocrats played a role of betto and the post administered the institution and was often put in ryo (bureau) and in tsukasa, only Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office) was put as the others.

Aristocrats played a role of betto and the post was often put in ryo (bureau) to administer the institution, and in tsukasa only Naizen no tsukasa (Imperial Table Office) had the post other than Okimi no tsukasa.
sen.cmt: Okimi no tsukasaに合わせ、Naizenshi→Naizen no tsukasaとし、意味が明確になるよう一部訳し直しました。
sen.e: Aristocrats served as 'betto' to administer the institution and in many cases the post was under the control of 'ryo' (bureau), and only Naizen no tsukasa (Imperial Table Office) other than Okimi no tsukasa had the position of 'betto' among others.

sen.j: このことから、この機関は時代が下っても重要な存在であったことがうかがい知れる。
sen.e: For this reason, the institution was an important one for a long time.
For this reason, the institution was an important one for a long time.
For this reason, the institution was an important one for a long time.

sen.j: 別当 設置時期不詳 正親司の総裁
sen.e: Betto, the time of establishment unknown, the presidency of Okimi no tsukasa.
Betto, the time of establishment unknown, the presidency of Okimi no tsukasa.
Betto, the time of establishment unknown, the presidency of Okimi no tsukasa.
Okimi (corresponding to Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade)) one member.
Kami (corresponding to Shorokuinojo [Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade]) one member.
sen.cmt: Okimi→Kamiに修正、カッコ表記修正
sen.e: Kami (corresponding to Shorokuinojo [Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade]) one member.
Jo (secretary) (corresponding to Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank), Junanai (Junior Seventh Rank)) one member.
Jo (secretary) (corresponding to Jushichiinoge [Junior Seventh Rank, Lower Grade]) one member.
sen.cmt: 「従六位従七位」→リンク先の単語と混ざっているため、ウェブ記載の「従七位下」を転記・訳文を修正しました。カッコ表記修正
sen.e: Jo (secretary) (corresponding to Jushichiinoge [Junior Seventh Rank, Lower Grade]) one member.

sen.j: 大令史（大初位上相当）一名 少令史（大初位下相当）一名
sen.e: Daireishi (corresponding to Jurokui, Daishoi (Great Initial Rank)) one member, shoreishi (corresponding to Jurokui, Daishoi) one member.
Daireishi (corresponding to Daihatsuinojo [Greater Initial Rank, Upper Grade]) one member, Shoreishi (corresponding to Daihatsuinoge [Greater Initial Rank, Lower Grade]) one member.
sen.cmt: 「従六位大初位」→リンク先の単語と混ざっているため、ウェブ記載の「大初位上」「大初位下」を転記・訳文を修正しました。Shoreishiの頭文字を大文字に変更、カッコ表記修正
sen.e: Daireishi (corresponding to Daihatsuinojo [Greater Initial Rank, Upper Grade]) one member, Shoreishi (corresponding to Daihatsuinoge [Greater Initial Rank, Lower Grade]) one member.
Shibu (low rank bureaucrats) ten members.
Shibu (low rank bureaucrats) ten members.
Shibu (low rank bureaucrats) ten members.
Kanjin shicho (a manservant doing odd jobs) one member.
Kanjin shicho (a manservant doing odd jobs) one member.
Kanjin shicho (a manservant doing odd jobs) one member.

sen.j: また延暦十五年（796年）の八月に、官人雑任が二名加えられた。
sen.e: In August 796, two Kanjin Zonin (lower-ranking government official) were added.
In September 796, two Kanjin Zonin (lower-ranking government official) were added.
In September 796, two Kanjin Zonin (lower-ranking government official) were added.
